Create an online game
Use simple mechanics to push 6 of the opponent's pieces out of the board!
The international version of the famous African strategy game!
Get rid of all of your opponent's pieces on a board that shrinks little by little!
Stack your pieces and control as many stacks as you can to win!
An enhanced tic-tac-toe where piece can encapsule other and prevent them to win.
An antiquity-war inspired game. Be the first to pierce your opponent's lines!
A hexagonal game of alignment. Insert your pieces on the board to capture your opponent's pieces!
The oldest strategy game still practiced widely. A territory control game.
Your goal is simple: reach the last line. But the piece you move depends on your opponent's last move!
Regroup your pieces to win. But your possible moves will often change!
The classical 4 in a row game!
Drop a piece, then rotate a quadrant. The first player to align 5 pieces wins!
Overlay your pieces and use two game mechanics to conserve your pieces. First player to run out of pieces loses!
Create a winning alignment. The problem: you don't pick the piece that you're placing on the board!
Align 5 of your pieces on a board where pieces slide!
Sandwich your opponent's pieces to dominate the board!
Immobilize one of your opponent's pyramids before your opponent does!
Be the first to push a mountain out of the board!
Put your hexagonal pieces next to another one, and create one of the 3 victorious shapes to win!
The Vikings checkers! Invaders must capture the King, defender must make him escape!
Align your pieces to score points, but beware, pieces can flip!
Four in a Row
Awal√©
Quarto
Tablut
Reversi
Go

Play

AwesomBoard

AwesomBoard is a website to play and learn the rules of various abstract strategy games with perfect information. Such games are games that do not include any randomness, agility, or hidden information. These games are played by two players, turn by turn.
It is not your turn!
You cannot clone a game. This feature might be implemented later.
The game has ended.

Play locally
See solution
You cannot move more than 3 of your pieces!
You don't have enough pieces to push that group!
You cannot push this piece because it is blocked by one of yours!
This line contains pieces of your opponent or empty spaces, which is forbidden.
This move is impossible, some landing spaces are occupied.
This space is not aligned with the current line.
Initial board and goal of the game
At Abalone, the goal of the game is to be the first player to push 6 opponent's pieces out of the board. Let us see how!
Moving a piece

At each turn, move one, two, or three pieces either along their line, or on their side. For your moves you can therefore choose between up to 6 directions. The pieces you move must be aligned and consecutive, and the move should land on an empty space (except to push, we will see that later). To make a move, click on one of your pieces, then click on an arrow to choose the move direction.

You're playing Dark, make any move!
Congratulations!
Pushing

To push one opponent piece, you must move at least two of your pieces. To push two opponent pieces, you must move three of your pieces. If one of your pieces is in the way, it will be impossible to push. You cannot move more than three pieces.

Only one push towards the right is possible here, find it. (You're playing Dark).
Congratulations! You know everything you need to start a game!
Failed!
You cannot distribute from the opponent's home.
You should choose a non-empty house to distribute.
You should distribute but you do not.
Sowing

Awal√© is a game of distribution (sowing) and capture. Its goal is to capture the most seeds. Let's see how seeds are sown. As you're playing first, the 6 houses on the top are yours.

Click on any of them to sow the seeds it contains: they will be sown clockwise, one seed per house.
Look at the 4 houses that follow clockwise the one you picked, they now contain 5 seeds. This is how seeds are sown: one by one from the house next to the one they come from, clockwise.
Big sowing

You are now the second player (on the bottom). When there are enough seeds to make a full turn, something else happens.

Sow the house that contains 12 seeds.
See, the house that you sowed has not been refilled, and the sowing immediately continued to the next house (which therefore contains two seeds).
Simple capture

After sowing, if the last seed falls in an opponent's house and if there is now two or three seeds in this house, the player captures these two or three seeds. Then, the player looks at the preceding house: if it is still in the opponent's side and contains two or three seeds, they are also captured. This continues until we reach either the player's side or a house containing neither two nor three seeds.

You are the second player, try to capture some pieces!
Well done! This was a simple capture, now let us see how to make multiple captures.
Failed. Try again and sow from the leftmost house.
Multiple captures

By sowing from your leftmost house, you will change the number of seeds in a house from 2 to 3, and from the preceding house from 1 to 2. As these are consecutive houses, all seeds in them will be captured.

Capture them.
Nice, you win 3 points from the first house, and 2 from the second!
Failed. Try again.
Interrupted capture

By clicking on your leftmost house, you end up on the 3rd house, which is capturable.

Do it.
Notice that because the second house was not capturable, the captured was interrupted and you have not captured the first house.
Capture on the other side only
Try to capture the two leftmost houses of the opponent.
Congratulations! Notice that the capture was interrupted when entering your territory: you cannot capture your own houses!
You have only captured one house, try again!
Do not starve

You have a very nice capture that seems possible: it seems that you can capture all the opponent's seeds!

Try it.
Sadly, you cannot capture here, otherwise the opponent could not play after you. When this happens, the move can be made, but no capture takes place!
Feeding is mandatory

You cannot let another player starve, meaning that if your opponent has no seeds anymore and if you can give them at least one, you have to do it.

Go ahead!
Congratulations! Note that you can choose to give your opponent the least number of seeds if it is better for you. It is often a good way to have easy captures!
End of the game

A game is won as soon as one player has captured 25 seeds, as that player has more than half of all the seeds.

Sow the house on the top right.
Also, as soon as on player cannot play, the other player captures all the seeds in its own side. Here, it was the first player's turn, and the second player has taken all the remaining seeds.
Your piece must land on one of the closest six triangles with the same color as the triangle on which the piece is.
You do not have enough tiles to exchange in order to capture this piece. Pick one of your piece and move it.
Your first click must be on the piece that you want to move, or on a piece of your opponent that you want to exchange against two tiles.
You cannot capture from an empty space.
You cannot capture your own pieces.
Board and goal of the game

Coerceo is played on a board like this, composed of hexagonal tiles, each comprising 6 triangles. The triangles are the spaces on which pieces move during the game. The tiles can be removed from the board (you will see how later). The dark pieces belong to the first player and can only move on the dark spaces, while the light pieces belong to the second player and can only move on the light spaces. The goal of the game is to capture all of the opponent's pieces.
Move

To move a piece, you need to:
  1. Click on one of your pieces.
  2. Click on one of the triangular space highlighted in yellow.
You can pass through the opponent's pieces. You're playing first, hence you're playing Dark.

Perform any move.
Congratulations! Let's see captures now.
Capture

Every piece has three neighboring triangular spaces (2 on the sides). When all neighboring spaces except one are occupied, and one opponent moves to that last free space, your piece is captured! However, it is possible to place a piece between 3 of the opponent's pieces (or 2 on the side) without being captured.

You're playing Light, make a capture.
Failed, you have not captured any piece.
Gain a tile

When a tile is empty, it can become removable from the board. For it to be removable, at least three of its sides must be free, and these should be neighboring sides. Note that if one empty tile, neighboring a tile that was just removed, also becomes removable, it will be removed too. For example, here, the topmost dark piece will not disconnect its tile when leaving it. But, by leaving the bottom left tile, two tiles will be removed.

Perform a move that lets you gain two tiles.
Failed, you have not gained the two tiles that you could, try again!
Exchanging a tile

When you have a tile, you can see it on the left of the board. As soon as you have two, you can click on an opponent's piece to capture it immediately instead of moving one of your pieces. This will cost you two tiles. If any tiles are removed during that turn, nobody will get them.

Gain some time and capture the last piece!
It's nice to move a piece, but you could have had the opponent's piece immediately by clicking on it!
Special capture

When a tile is removed from the board during your turn, some of the opponent's pieces may have lost their last free neighboring space, they will therefore be captured! If this happens to one of your piece during your turn, it will however stay on the board.

A move that demonstrate both of these things can be done on this board by Light. Try it!

Congratulations! See, your piece no longer had any empty neighboring space after you have gained the tile, but it stayed on the board as it was your turn. However, the opponent's piece has disappeared because the tile's capture has removed its last empty neighboring space.
Invalid coordinate, please select a piece on the board.
You must select a piece or a stack of your color.
You must select a stack.
This stack cannot be moved because all 6 of its neighbors are occupied. You must select a stack with strictly less than 6 neighbors.
This stack cannot move because it could never land on another piece.
A stack must always be moved by as many spaces as there are pieces in the stack.
The stack must land on an occupied space.
Moving

At Dvonn, each hexagonal space contains a stack of pieces. If no number is indicated on a stack, it means that it only contains one piece. The number written on a stack indicates the number of pieces within that stack, hence the number of points its owner gets. The owner of a stack is the one that has a piece at the top of the stack. Only the owner of a stack can move it. A stack cannot be moved if it is surrounded by 6 other stacks. A stack is moved by as many spaces as there are pieces within, in a straight line, and it should land on an occupied space. This line cannot move along the vertex of two neighboring spaces, as would a vertical move. Therefore, there are six possible directions. The player with dark pieces starts.

You're playing Dark, click on a stack and move it by one space.
Disconnection

Pieces with a lightning strike are called "sources". When a stack is not directly nor indirectly connected to a source, it is removed from the board.

You're playing Dark, try to disconnect the stack of 4 pieces from your opponent. There are two ways of doing that, one is better than the other: try to find that one!

You have successfully disconnected the stack of 4 pieces of your opponent, but on the next move your opponent will be able to move on your new stack, and to win the game! There exists a better outcome of this situation, try to find it.

Nice, you have disconnected 4 pieces of your opponent, and your new stack cannot be reached by your opponent! Your opponent therefore lost 5 points: 4 from the disconnected stack, and one from the stack on which you moved. Disconnected stacks will not be visible at the next turn.
Moving on a source

You are allowed to move your stacks on any other stack. This means that you can take control of a source by moving one of your stack on top of it. This way, you know that this stack may never be disconnected, as it contains a source.

You're playing Dark and you can take control of a source, do it!
You have not taken possession of a source, try again.
Congratulations! However, note that your opponent could later take possession of one of your stack that contains a source, so watch out when you take control of sources!
Passing

It can happen that you have no possible move to make. If this is the case, and if your opponent can still move, you must pass your turn.

This is a situation that occurs here for Dark.

When no more move is possible for both players, the game ends and the player with the most points wins.

Make your last move.
Congratulations, you won 6 - 0!
Bad idea, by moving on the source you would have won a point.
You do not have pieces of this type anymore.
You must put your piece on an empty square or on a smaller piece.
You must pick your piece among the remaining ones.
You must pick one of your remaining piece or one piece on the board that is the biggest of its square.
You must select a different landing square than the square where the move originates from.
You are performing a move, you must select a landing square.
Goal of the game
The goal of Encapsule is to align three of your pieces. Here, we have a victory of the dark player.
Putting a piece

This is the initial board. You're playing Dark.

Pick one of your piece on the side of the board and put it on the board.

Another possible action is to move one of your pieces that is already on the board.

Click on your dark piece and then on any empty square of the board.
Particularity

At Encapsule, pieces encapsulate each other. It is therefore possible to have up to three pieces per square! However, only the biggest piece of each square counts: you cannot win with a piece that is "hidden" by a bigger piece. Similarly, you cannot move a piece if it is encapsulated by a bigger piece. Finally, you cannot encapsulate a piece with a smaller piece. You're playing Dark and you can win now in various ways.

Try to win by making a move, and not by putting a new piece on the board.
The move distance of your phalanx puts it out of the board.
There is something in the way of your phalanx.
Your phalanx must be bigger than the one you are capturing.
This square is not aligned with the selected piece.
A single piece can only move by one square.
A single piece cannot make a capture.
This square is not aligned with the direction of the phalanx.
A phalanx can't contain pieces outside of the board.
A phalanx cannot contain an empty square.
A phalanx cannot contain a piece of the opponent.
Initial board
This is the initial board of Epaminondas. The top line is the starting line of Light. The bottom line is the starting line of Dark.
Goal of the game (1/2)

After multiple moves, if at the beginning of its turn, a player has more pieces on the opponent's starting line than the number of pieces the opponent has on the player's starting line, the player wins. Here, it's Dark's turn to play: Dark has therefore won.
Goal of the game (2/2)
Here, it is Light's turn. Light wins because they have two pieces on Dark's starting line, and Dark only has one on Light's starting line.

Here is the starting board. Dark plays first. Let's start with moving a single piece:
  1. Click on a piece.
  2. Click on a empty neighboring square.
Congratulations, you are in advance. But this is not the exercise here, try again.
This is how you move a single piece.
Moving a phalanx

Let us now see how to move multiple pieces along a line, which is called a phalanx:
  1. Click on the first piece of the phalanx.
  2. Click on the last piece of the phalanx.
  3. Click on one of the squares highlighted in yellow; you can move your phalanx up to a distance equal to its length.

Move a phalanx!
Failed! You moved only one piece.

Congratulations! The moved pieces can be horizontally, vertically, or diagonally aligned. The move should be made along this axis, forward or backwards. There can be no opponent nor holes in the phalanx.

In order to capture pieces of the opponent:
  1. It must be aligned with the phalanx you are moving.
  2. It must be strictly shorter than your phalanx.
  3. The first piece of your phalanx should land on the first piece of the opponent's phalanx that you want to capture.

Capture a phalanx.

Congratulations, you made it! Note that the diagonal phalanx was not aligned with your phalanx, hence even if it is longer, this does not prevent you from capturing some of its pieces on another alignment.
Failed, you have not captured the phalanx.
You can only capture when 4 or more of your pieces are aligned, and it is not the case.
You must select a valid capture that contains 4 pieces or more.
There are still possible captures to be done.
Pieces must be inserted in spaces on the edge of the board.
You must select a valid placement direction.
You must select a placement with a direction alongside the insertion space.
You cannot place a piece on a complete line.
This piece belongs to two captures. Please select another piece in the capture you'd like to make.
You must click on an arrow to select your destination.
You cannot insert a piece here, as all lines are full. Select another space.

The goal of Gipf is to capture the opponent's piece so that the opponent can no longer play. This is the initial board. Each player has 12 pieces on the side and 3 pieces on the board. When, at its turn, a player has no more pieces on the side, that player cannot play anymore and loses the game. The first player plays with the dark pieces, the second player plays with the light pieces.

Pieces can only enter the board through the edges. To insert a new piece:
  1. Click on a space on the edge of the board.
  2. If that space was already occupied, click on the arrow that indicates the direction in which you want to push the piece(s) already on the corresponding line.
You cannot push when a line is full.

You're playing Dark, insert a piece.
Capture (1/3)

To capture, you must align 4 of your own pieces, which will be the first 4 captured pieces. There are multiple important aspects of a capture:
  1. When 4 pieces are captured, all pieces that are directly aligned with these 4 pieces are also captured.
  2. As soon as there is an empty space on the line, the capture stops.
  3. Your own pieces that are captured go back to your stock. Your opponent's pieces however are really captured and do not go back to your opponent's stock.
  4. If you create a line of 4 of your opponent's pieces, it will be at the beginning of your opponent's turn that your opponent can capture them. This means that a turn happens in three phases:
    1. Pick the capture(s) resulting from the last move of your opponent (by clicking on it).
    2. Make your insertion.
    3. Pick the capture(s) resulting from your move (by clicking on it).

You're playing Dark, you can make a capture, do it.
Congratulations, you have gotten 4 of your pieces back. This is not the most useful capture. Let's now see how captures can really be useful.
Capture (2/3)

Here, there are three different ways of capturing.
  1. One way does not capture any of your opponent's pieces.
  2. Another way captures one of your opponent's pieces.
  3. The last way captures two of your opponent's pieces.


Pick the last one.
Congratulations, you have gotten back 4 of your pieces and captured 2 of the opponent's. The most you can get is 3 per capture.
Failed, the best capture was taking 2 of your opponent's pieces
Capture (3/3)

Here, you must capture at the beginning of your turn. This is due to a move of your opponent at the previous turn (even though this is a fictitious board for pedagogical purpose). After your capture, by performing the right move you can even capture two more of your opponent's pieces! Keep it mind that the most useful in a capture is to take your opponent's pieces.
Congratulations, you have gotten 12 of your pieces back and captured 2 of your opponent's pieces.
Failed, the best capture takes 2 of your opponent's pieces.
This move is a ko, you must play somewhere else before you can play in this intersection again.
We are in the counting phase, you must mark stones as dead or alive or accept the current board by passing your turn.
You cannot accept before the counting phase.
This intersection is already occupied.
You cannot commit suicide.
Preliminary information

The game of Go is played on a board called a Goban, and the stones are placed on the intersections. The traditional board is made of 19x19 intersections, but on this website we have the 13x13 board. (For shorter parts, 9x9 and 5x5 boards exist, but are not yet available here). For this tutorial, we will use a smaller board for pedagogical purposes.

The goal of the game is to have the most points at the end of the game. We call "territories" the intersections that are empty and isolated from the rest of the Goban by the stones of a single player. Here, Dark has 9 territories on the left, and Light has 8 on the right. The top part belongs to no one. Each player's score at the end of the game is the sum of that player's territories and captures.

An isolated stone, like the one in the middle here, has 4 neighboring intersections (not 8, because we do not count diagonals). It is said of a group which has exactly 2 free neighboring squares, that this group has two liberties. If Dark plays on the last liberty of the light stone, this stone is removed from the Goban (captured) and Dark earns one point.

The light piece only has one liberty left, play there.
Congratulations, you have earned one point.
Failed, try again by playing on one of the intersections directly next to the light stone.
Capturing multiple stones

Stones that are connected horizontally or vertically must be captured at the same time, and are not capturable in isolation.

The light group here only has one liberty left, capture it.
Congratulations, you have earned three points and formed a territory.
Failed, you have not captured the group. Play on the last liberty of that group.
Suicide

In Go, suicide is forbidden. If putting a piece on an intersection removes the last liberty of your group and does not capture any stone, playing on that intersection would be a suicide and is therefore forbidden. Here, the top left intersection is a suicide for Light. On the bottom right, it would be a suicide for Dark, and on the bottom left it is not a suicide for any player.
Life and death (death)

From the capture rule follows the life and death notion: dead stones are stones that are definitely capturable (without losing anything else). Alive stones are stones that can never be captured. From the capture rule, Dark can play inside Light's territory and make a capture. In this case, we say that Light has only one eye (its last liberty) and that Light is dead (even if not yet captured). At the end of the game, the dead stones will count as captures, and the intersections they occupy as territories.
Life and death (eyes)

Here, Light cannot play on the top left, nor on the bottom left. Light will never be able to capture Dark. We say that Dark has two eyes (the eye on the top left, and the one on the bottom left) and that Dark is alive.
Seki

If Dark plays on the middle line, Light will play on the opposite intersection and capture Dark. Similarly, if Light plays on the middle line, Dark will capture Light. In other words, there is no point in playing on the middle line. In that case, we say that stones in the middle are alive by Seki, and that both intersections in the middle are neutral.
Ko

A player, by putting a stone, cannot go back to an identical state of the Goban as before, in order to avoid an endless game.

Capture the light stone.

Now, if Light tries to recapture the stone that Dark has just put on the Goban, this one would go back to its previous state, opening the door for an endless game. This intersection is therefore marked with a red square, to remind the players that this intersection is forbidden. This rule is called the Ko. The trick for Light is to try to create a big enough threat so that Dark must answer immediately, and does not have the time to protect its last stone, so that Light can capture it right after.

When a player feels that there is no advantage to putting a new stone, that player can pass a turn. The game phase stops when both players pass consecutively, and we move on to the counting phase. The dead groups are then marked by clicking on them. Every intersection in a player's territory earns that player a point. The winner is the one with most points.

A last stone is dead, mark it.

Congratulations, Dark has 15 territories and 3 light stones still present, called prisoners at the end of the game. The intersections where the prisoners are count as Dark's territory Light has 8 territories and 1 prisoner. The end result is therefore 18 - 9 for Dark.
Failed, try again.
This piece is not of the color you have to play.
You can only move forward, orthogonally or diagonally.
This move is blocked by another piece.
You must play with the selected piece.

At Kamisado, there are two ways to win the game: either by moving one of your pieces on the opponent's starting line, or by forcing the opponent to make a move that blocks the entire game. Here, Dark wins because its brown piece is on Light's starting line, on the top left.
Initial board and initial move

Here is the initial board. At Kamisado, pieces can only move forward, vertically or diagonally. You're playing first, with dark pieces, you can make your first move.

Click on the piece of your choice and click on the landing square.
Perfect! Note that each of your piece has a different color.

Let us now consider the move of Light, after the blue piece has been moved by Dark. All moves after the initial move must be made from the piece that corresponds to the color of the square upon which the last move ended. Here, the last move ended on the pink square, hence the pink piece must move. It is already selected, you do not have to click on it.

Move it on a blue square.
You have not moved your pink piece on a blue square!
Stuck situation

Dark moved to another pink square, hence you have to move your pink piece again. However, your pink piece is stuck! In this case, you must pass your turn. Dark will now have to play by moving its pink piece.
Victory by blocking

At any time, if a player blocks the entire game, that player loses. In other words, if a player forces its opponent to move a piece that the opponent cannot move, and the player cannot move its own piece of the same color, then that player loses. Here, you're playing Dark and you can force your opponent to create such a situation, hence you can force your opponent to lose!

Try to make this move.

Perfect! Your opponent must move its green piece on the orange square, forcing you to play with your orange piece. Your orange piece will be stuck and you will have to pass your turn. Your opponent will have to pass its turn too because its orange piece is also stuck: the game is completely stuck. In this case, the last player to have moved a piece loses. Here, your opponent will have moved its green piece last, you therefore win!
Your move should have a length equal to the number of pieces that exist on the same line.
You cannot jump over the opponent's pieces.
This piece has no possible move, select another one.
A move must be orthogonal or diagonal

At Lines of Actions, the goal is to group your pieces contiguously, orthogonally and/or diagonally. Here, Dark wins the game: Dark's pieces are forming a single group, while Light's pieces form three groups.

Here is the initial board. Moves can be made orthogonally or diagonally. The length of a move is equal to the number of pieces that are on the line of the move. Note that there is a helping indicator to let you know where a piece can land when you select it.

You're playing Dark, make the first move!
Jumping

During a move, it is possible to jump above your own pieces. But it is forbidden to jump over the opponent's pieces.

You're playing Dark, make a jump over one of your pieces on the following board.
Failed. You did not jump over one of your pieces.

Here is a different board. Pick the dark piece in the middle (line 4, column 4) and observe its possible moves. Horizontally, this piece can move only of one square because it is the only piece on this line. Vertically, this piece can move of three squares because there are in total three pieces on that vertical line. But it can only go up, as below it the landing square is occupied by one of your pieces. Diagonally, only one move is possible: on the diagonal that contains three pieces, only in the direction where it does not jump over one of the opponent's pieces. On the other diagonal, there are too many pieces to end the move on the board.

Make one of these moves.
Failed. This was not one of the expected moves.
Capturing

If a move ends on an opponent's pieces, this one is captured and removed from the board. However, a move cannot end on one of the player's pieces. Watch out, having less pieces at Lines of Action makes a victory easier, as there are less pieces to regroup! If a player has only one piece, that player wins the game.

On the following board, try to capture one piece with Dark.
Tie

In the special case where a move ends up connecting all pieces of both player, simultaneously, then the game ends up with a tie.

You're playing Dark, force the tie in one move.
Please put your piece in an incomplete column.

The board at Four in a Row is made of 7 columns and 6 rows, and it is initially empty. The first player plays Dark, the second plays Light. The goal is to be the first to align 4 of its pieces (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally).
Dropping a piece
Click on any space in any column.
As you can see, the piece falls at the bottom of the column.
Victory
You're playing Dark. Place your piece so that you create a horizontal alignment of 4 of your pieces.
You won!
Failed, you have not aligned 4 pieces and missed an opportunity to win.
Other victory
You can also align 4 pieces diagonally or vertically.
If the quadrant to turn is neutral, please just use move without rotation.
No quadrant is neutral, you must pick a quadrant to rotate.
The initial Pentago board is made of 6x6 spaces, subdivided in 4 quadrants, which can each rotate.
The goal at Pentago is to align 5 of your pieces. In the following board, Dark wins.
Simple move

At their turn, players put a piece on the board and possibly rotate one quadrant. As long as there are neutral quadrants, i.e., quadrants that would not change after being rotated, a player may skip rotating a quadrant. To do this, you have to click on the crossed circle that appears at the center of the board when it is possible.

Do it.
You have made a move with a rotation. This tutorial step is about moves without rotations!
Move with rotation

After putting a piece, arrows will appear on non-neutral quadrants.

Click on one of them and see the rotation!
You made a move without rotation, try again!
Congratulations! Note that if all quadrants are neutral after you have put your piece, there will be no rotation.
You must move your pieces upward.
Your piece must land on the board or on 4 other pieces.
You cannot land on this space.
You cannot capture.
Your first capture is invalid.
Your second capture is invalid.

At Pylos, the goal is to be the last to play. To do this, you have to save up your pieces. As soon as a player puts its last piece, that player loses the game immediately. Here is what the initial board looks like, it is a board of 4 x 4 squares. This board will become a pyramid, little by little. It will be filled by the pieces of your stock. Each player has 15 pieces.

When it is your turn, you can always drop one of your piece on an empty square. The gray squares are where you can drop your pieces.

Click on one of the squares to drop a piece there.
There you go, as simple as that.
Climbing

When 4 pieces form a square, it is possible to put a fifth piece on top. However, when that happens, you can save a piece by climbing instead of dropping a piece. To climb:
  1. Click on one of your free pieces, which should be lower than the landing square.
  2. Click on an empty landing square, higher than your selected piece.

Go ahead, climb!

Congratulations!
Some important notes:
  1. You cannot move a piece that is directly below another one.
  2. Of course, you cannot move the opponent's pieces.
  3. You can only climb when the landing square is higher than the starting square.
Square (1/2)

When the piece you just moved or dropped is the fourth one of a square of your color, you can choose anywhere on the board one or two of your pieces. These pieces will be removed from the board, allowing you to save up one or two pieces. A chosen piece must not be directly below another piece. A chosen piece can be the piece you just placed. You're playing Dark.

Form a square, then click twice on one of the four pieces to remove only that one.
Congratulations, you have saved up one piece.
Square (2/2)

You're playing Dark.

Do like in the previous step, but this time click on two different pieces.
Failed, you only captured one piece.
Failed, you did not capture any piece.
Congratulations, you have saved up two pieces.
You must give a piece.
That piece is already on the board.
You cannot give the piece that was in your hands.

Quarto is an alignment game. The goal is to align four pieces that have at least one common aspect:
  • their color (light or dark),
  • their size (big or small),
  • their pattern (empty or dotted),
  • their shape (round or square).
Here, we have a board with a victory by an alignment of dark pieces.
Placement

Every placement occurs in two steps: placing the piece you have in hand (in the small square) on a square of the board, and picking a piece that the opponent will have to place, by clicking on one of the pieces inside the dotted square. If you prefer, the order of these two steps can be reversed. Keep in mind that the second click confirms the move.

Make a move.
Perfect!
Situation

We have here a tricky situation.

Analyze the board and play your move, carefully paying attention not to let the opponent win on the next move.
Well done!
You must pick a space from the edge of the board.
Goal of the game.

At Quixo, the goal is to align 5 of your pieces. The first player plays with dark pieces, the second with light pieces. The board is made of 25 spaces spread over a 5x5 square. Every piece has a neutral side, a light side, and a dark side.
What a move looks like (without animation)

When it is your turn:
  1. Click on one of your pieces or on a neutral one. You cannot choose a piece of the opponent. You can only choose a piece from the edge of the board.
  2. Pick a direction in which you want to send the piece (by clicking on the arrow).
You have to imagine that the piece you picked has been moved to the other side of the board, in the chosen direction. Once on the other side, all pieces will move by one space in the opposing direction. Afterwards, if the piece was neutral, it will become yours and takes your color.

For example, take the bottom right neutral piece, and move it to the left (you're playing Light).
See how the four dark pieces have been moved one space to the right. The neutral piece has been move 4 pieces to the left and has become light.

You already know everything you need in order to play, but there is one last particularity. If you create a line of 5 of your pieces, you win. If you create a line of 5 of your opponent's pieces, you lose. If you create both, you lose too!

You can win with this board, try it. You're playing Light.
Congratulations, you won!
Your move should switch at least one piece.

At Reversi, the pieces are double sided: one dark side for the first player, one light side for the second player. When one piece is flipped, its owner changes. The player owning the most pieces at the end of the game wins. Here, Dark has 28 points and Light has 36, hence Light wins.
Capture (1/2)

At the beginning of the game, pieces are placed as shown here. For a move to be legal, it must sandwich at least one piece of the opponent between the piece you're putting and another of your pieces.

Do any move by clicking to put your piece Dark plays first.
Capture (2/2)

A move can also capture a bigger line, and more than one lines at a time You're playing light here.

Play on the bottom left to see an example.
Lower and more to the left, please.
Passing a turn

If, during its turn, a player has no move that would allow that player to flip a piece, that player must pass Moreover, if the next player could not play neither, the game ends before the board is full, and points are counted in the usual way.
You can only rebound on dark spaces.
You can only rebound on empty spaces.
You must pick one of your pyramids first.
You must pick one of your pyramids.
You can move one or two spaces, not .
S√¢h√¢r√¢ is played on a board where each space is a triangle. Each player has six pyramids.

At S√¢h√¢r√¢, the goal of the game is to immobilize one of the opponent's pyramids. To do so, you have to occupy all neighboring space of that pyramid. Here, Light has lost because its leftmost pyramid is immobilized.
Simple step

To immobilize your opponent, you have to move your pyramids. When a pyramid shares its vertices with light spaces, it can move on these spaces (we call this a simple step). You're the first player, playing with the dark pyramids.
  1. Click on one of your pyramids.
  2. Click on one of its two or three neighboring spaces in order to move your pyramid there.

Do any simple step.
You have made a double step, which is good but it is the next exercise!
Double step

When a pyramid shares its vertices with dark spaces, it can move one or two steps. To do so:
  1. Click on the pyramid to move.
  2. Click on one of the 6 destinations that you can reach in two steps: the 6 neighboring light spaces of the 3 dark spaces that are neighbors of your pyramid.
Failed! You have made a single step.
You cannot insert a piece when you have already selected a piece.
You cannot insert a piece, all your pieces are already on the board.
You do not have enough strength to push.
You cannot push and turn at the same time.
Your push is invalid: it is either not straight, is not pushing anything, or is leaving the board.

The goal at Siam is to be the first to push a mountain out of the board. The initial board contains three mountains, and no pieces are initially on the board. During its turn, a player can do one of the following three actions:
  1. Put a new piece on the board.
  2. Change the orientation of one of its piece, and optionally move it.
  3. Take one of its pieces out of the board.
Inserting a piece

Each player has 5 pieces in total. As long as you do not have 5 pieces on the board, you can insert new pieces. To do so:
  1. Click on one of the big arrows alongside the board.
  2. Click on one of the small arrows that appeared on the landing square of your piece. This is the direction in which your piece will be oriented.

Insert a piece on the board.

We will distinguish here "moving" and "pushing". A move is made from a piece's square to an empty neighboring square, horizontally or vertically. During that move, you can also move the piece out of the board. To move a piece:
  1. Click on it.
  2. Click on one of the 4 arrows to pick the direction in which it will move. You can also click on the middle dot to change the piece's orientation without moving it.
  3. Click on one of the 4 arrows on the landing square to pick its orientation.

Try to move the piece that is on the board one square upwards and to orient it downwards.
Congratulations, you made a side-slip!
Moving a piece out of the board

To move a piece out of the board, you do not have to pick an orientation after the move.

Get that piece out of the board!
Congratulations, even if in this context it was not a useful move.
Failed, the piece is still on the board.

When the landing square of your move is occupied, we use the term "push". In order to push, multiple conditions must hold:
  1. Your piece must already be oriented in the direction of the push.
  2. The number of the pieces (opponent's or not) that are facing yours (called the resistants) must be smaller than the number of pieces that are oriented in the same direction as the push, yourself included (the pushers).
  3. The number of mountains on that line must be smaller or equal to the difference between the pushers and the resistants.
Your piece on the top right cannot push because there is one mountain too much. Your piece on the bottom right can push.

Do it.

The game ends when a mountain is pushed out of the board. If you pushed it and nobody is in front of you, you're the winner. However, if you were pushing an opponent oriented in the same direction as you, your opponent will win because that piece is closer to the mountain. However, if that opponent is closer to the mountain but not oriented towards it, victory will be yours.

You have two ways of ending the game here: you can either win, or lose. Choose correctly!
Failed, you lost.
You cannot move yet. Pick a space where you will put a new piece.
Several groups are of the same size, you must pick the one to keep.
You cannot choose which part to keep when one is smaller than the other.
You cannot put new pieces anymore. Pick a piece to move.
You must choose one of the biggest groups to keep it.
You cannot pick an empty space. Pick one of the biggest groups.
You must put this piece next to another piece.
This move does not disconnect your opponent's pieces. Try again with another piece.
You lost one of your pieces during this move. There is a way to disconnect an opponent's piece without losing any of yours, try again!

Six is a game without board, where pieces are placed on the side of each other, in a contiguous block. Each player has 21 pieces, with one for each player already on the board. The goal of the game is to form one of the three winning shapes with your pieces.
Victory (line)

On this board, by putting your piece at the right place, you can align six of your pieces and win the game

Find the victory. You're playing Dark.
Victory (circle)

On this board, by putting your piece at the right place, you can form a circle with six of your pieces and win the game.

Find the victory. You're playing Dark.
Congratulations! Note that if a piece is inside the circle, it does not change anything.
Victory (triangle)

On this board, by putting your piece at the right place, you can form a triangle with six of your pieces and win the game.

Find the victory. You're playing Dark.
Second phase

After 40 turns, your pieces have all been placed and we move on to the second phase of the game. You now have to move your pieces, paying attention not to remove a piece that was preventing the opponent's victory. From now on, if after move, on or more pieces are disconnected from the largest group of pieces, these will be taken out of the game.

You're playing Dark. Make a move that disconnects one of your opponent's pieces.
Congratulations, your opponent now has one piece less and you're closer to victory!
Victory by disconnection

During the second phase of the game, on top of normal victories (line, circle, triangle), you can win by disconnection. If at any time, at least one player does not have enough pieces to win (less than 6), the game ends. The one with the most pieces wins. In case they both have the same number of pieces, it's a draw.

Here, you're playing Dark and you can win. Do it!
Special disconnection

During a disconnection, two or more groups could have the same size, in which case you will have to click on the group you wish to keep.

You're playing Dark, play such a move!
This move has not cut the board in two equal halves.
Failed. You did cut the board in two but you kept the half where you're in minority. Therefore, you lost! Try again.
You cannot land on an occupied square.
Once you left the central throne, you cannot return to it.
Soldiers cannot sit on the throne.
Something is in the way.

Tablut is a strategy game that was played by the Vikings. The goal of the game is different for each player. The attacker plays first. Its pieces (dark) are close to the edges. Its goal is to capture the king, which is in the center of the board. The defender plays second. Its pieces (light) are in the middle. Its goal is to put the king on one of the 4 thrones in the corners. Note that the square in which the king starts, in the center of the board, is also a throne.

All pieces move the same way. Similarly to a rook in chess, a piece can move:
  1. By as many squares as you want.
  2. Without going over another piece or stopping on another piece.
  3. Horizontally or vertically.
  4. Only the king can land on a throne.
To move a piece, click on it and then on its landing square.

This is the initial board, do the first move.
Capturing a soldier (1/2)

All pieces except the king, attackers and defenders, are soldiers. To capture them, they have to be sandwiched between two of your pieces. By getting too close, an attacker's soldier is in danger.

Capture it.
Congratulations, that will teach him a lesson!
Failed, you missed an opportunity to capture a piece of the opponent.
Capturing a soldier (2/2)

A second way to capture a soldier is against an empty throne. The King has moved and endangered one of its soldiers.

Capture it.
Congratulations, one less defender. But keep an eye on the king, it is the most important.
Failed, you did not do the expected move.
Capturing the king (1/2)

To capture the king, two soldiers are not enough. For the first solution, the four squares neighbor to the king (horizontally and vertically) must be occupied by your soldiers. This also works if the king is on the throne.

Capture the king.
Failed, you let the king run away.
Capturing the king (2/2)

Another way to capture the king is to immobilize it against an edge of the board. Note that the king cannot be captured next to a throne.

Capture the king.
The King is dead, long live the King. Congratulations, you won.
You cannot put a new ring after the tenth turn.
You cannot put a marker in a ring before placing all of your rings.
The direction of your move is invalid: a move is made along a straight line.
You can only capture your own markers.
You must pick one of your own rings to move.
Your ring must land on an empty space.
A ring can only jump over markers or empty spaces, not over another ring.
Your ring must land on the first empty space after a group of markers.
When you capture markers, you must take one of your ring as well by clicking on it.
Failed! You need to align 5 markers of your color in order to get them, and to get a ring at the same time.
Failed! You can capture two rings in total, by capturing two times 5 of your markers. Try again.

The goal at Yinsh is to capture three rings in total. The rings taken are shown on the top left for the dark player, and on the bottom right for the light player. Here, Dark won the game. Note that on the board you have two types of pieces for each player: rings (empty circles) and markers (full circles).
Initial board and placement phase

The initial board is empty. At the beginning of the game, each player puts one of its ring on the board at their turn. This phase stops when all rings have been placed on the board. Put one of your ring on the board by clicking the space where you want to place it.
Putting a marker

Once the initial phase is done and all rings are on the board, you need to place markers on the board. To do so, put a marker in a ring by clicking on that ring. Then, the ring must be moved in a straight line, in any direction. A ring cannot pass through other rings during its move. If it goes over a group of markers, your move must stop at the first empty space after that group. All markers in the group are then flipped and their color change.

You're playing Dark, do a move.
Getting a ring by aligning 5 markers

Finally, the last mechanic you need is to be able to get a ring from the board in order to gain points. To do so, you need to align 5 markers of your color. You can then get these markers by clicking on them, and then get one of your ring by clicking on it. You will then have one more point. You must capture when you can.

You're playing Dark, perform a capture!
Compound captures

During a turn, you could have to choose between multiple captures, or you could even capture multiple times! During the capture selection, if you see that the marker you clicked belongs to two captures, you have to click on a second marker to avoid any ambiguity.

Here, you can capture two rings, do it!
You cannot pick a piece of the opponent.
You must click on an empty space.
Your landing space should be empty or contain a piece of the opponent.
You must pick one of your pieces.
You cannot pass your turn.
You must drop your piece on an empty space.
You must pass your turn.
You have selected an empty space, you must select one of your own pieces.
You're not allowed to send a message here.
This message is forbidden.
You are already in a game. Finish it or cancel it first.
You are offline. Log in to join a game.
